docs.lead_paragraph: The president sought out black and female voters in California, Oregon and Washington.

headline.seo: Obama on Campaign Swing in Western States
headline.main: Obama Tries to Shore Up the Party Base With a Western Campaign Swing
headline.print_headline: Obama Tries to Shore Up the Party Base With a Western Campaign Swing

docs.snippet: The president sought out black and female voters in California, Oregon and Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. -- President Obama began his four-day campaign swing on Wednesday to fortify a Democratic firewall on the West Coast, telling a crowded rally here to ''defy the conventional wisdom just like you did in 2008,'' when Oregon overwhelmingly backed him for president. With two weeks to go until the midterm elections, Mr. Obama is trying desperately to shore up the Democratic base, appealing to voters in Oregon, Washington and California -- traditionally blue states where Republicans have been running competitive campaigns.

headline.main: Obama Tries to Shore Up the Party Base With a Western Campaign Swing

byline.original: By HELENE COOPER; Jeff Zeleny contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: Updated | 6:23 p.m. On Wednesday, as Britain's government unveiled plans to slash public spending, eliminate nearly half a million jobs and raise the retirement age from 65 to 66, the British largely resisted the urge to follow the lead of their French neighbors and flood the streets in angry and sporadically violent protest at the austerity measures.
docs.abstract: Why are the French in the streets this week, in response to government austerity measures, while the British are content to post wry remarks on Twitter mocking their well-heeled finance minister for having changed his name from Gideon to George, to sound less posh?

docs.lead_paragraph: A young, Harvard-educated prison librarian near Boston tells his story.

headline.seo: Avi Steinberg’s Prison Library Tales in ‘Running the Books’
headline.main: The Readers Behind Bars Put Books to Many Uses
headline.print_headline:
Books Behind Bars,
Put to Many Uses

docs.snippet: A young, Harvard-educated prison librarian near Boston tells his story.

docs.lead_paragraph: In some ways, Regina Milgram-Bossong acknowledges, she has it easy. Her parents live nearby in central New Jersey. Despite the usual run of late-life health problems -- her father, 84, is diabetic and has had a hip replacement; her mother survived ovarian cancer and last year underwent heart valve surgery -- they're still managing well in the house where Ms. Milgram-Bossong grew up.
docs.abstract: Which is harder: caring for an elderly parent by oneself, or slogging through it with siblings?
docs.snippet: Which is harder: caring for an elderly parent by oneself, or slogging through it with siblings?
